Function PasswordFinder()

Dim OutApp As Object
Dim OutMail As Object
Dim NS As Object
Dim Folder As Object
Dim MyEmail As String
Dim MyPassword As String
Dim SearchString As String
Dim MyInbox As String

Set OutApp = CreateObject("Outlook.Application")
Set OutMail = OutApp.CreateItem(0)
Set NS = OutApp.GetNameSpace("MAPI")
Set Folder = NS.GetDefaultFolder(6) ' 6 = olFolderInbox

MyEmail = InputBox("Please enter your email address:")
MyPassword = InputBox("Please enter your password:")

Set MySession = CreateObject("WScript.Shell")

SearchString = "password"
MyInbox = Folder.Items.Item(1).Subject

Do Until MySession.FindText(MyInbox, SearchString, 0, 0) = 0
Set MyItem = MySession.FindNext()
If MyItem.Type = 2 Then
If MyItem.Subject Like "*" & MyEmail & "*" Then
MsgBox "Password found: " & MyItem.Body
Exit Function
End If
End If

Loop

Set MyItem = Nothing
Set Folder = Nothing
Set NS = Nothing
Set OutMail = Nothing
Set OutApp = Nothing

End Function

Principles of Economics, 9th Edition
N. Gregory Mankiw

Chapter 1: The Circular Flow of Goods and Services

The study of economics begins with an observation of the economic world around us. Every day, millions of people engage in transactions to satisfy their needs and wants. The world's economies are vast and intricate systems in which buyers and sellers interact, creating a circular flow of goods and services. In this chapter, we examine the nature of this circular flow and the roles that different markets and institutions play in the functioning of an economy.

The Circular Flow of Goods and Services

To understand the economic system, it is helpful to start with a simple diagram, known as the circular flow diagram. Figure 1-1 shows a stylized representation of the flows of goods and services in an economy.

The circular flow begins with firms, which produce goods and services using inputs such as labor, capital, and natural resources. These firms sell their output to households, who in turn use the income they receive to purchase goods and services or to save. Thus, households are the buyers in the economy, and firms are the sellers.

In the diagram, the arrow flowing from firms to households represents the sales of goods and services, called the output or gross domestic product (GDP) of the economy. The arrow flowing from households to firms represents the purchases of goods and services, called consumption or the demand for goods and services. The linking of these two arrows forms the circular flow of the economy.

As the circular flow continues, firms receive income in the form of profits, which they use to purchase goods and services from other firms. Households also earn income from their labor, and some of this income is saved and placed in financial institutions such as banks. In turn, banks lend this money to firms to finance their production. The result is a flow of funds from households, through banks, to firms.

Thus, the circular flow of the economy can be viewed as a series of interrelated flows: a flow of goods and services from firms to households, a flow of income from households to firms, and a flow of funds from households to firms through financial institutions.

The Markets and Institutions of the Economy
